title: Book font
content:
This is from a book printed in the mid ’60s, on a typesetting machine that allowed for ligatures (I’ve seen some ‘ﬃ’s) but not kerning—even the italic is unkerned. My scanner doesn’t work under Linux, so I have a photo; if higher quality is needed for an ID I’ll scan it again.  
 Some features of the font I’ve noticed:  
• The leg of the `Q' begins on the bottom-outside of the circle.  
• Quotes & apostrophes are smaller than the commas.  
• Four-headed `W' with separate serifs.  
• The left leg of the `M' is slightly slanted, the right leg is straight.  
• The square brackets `[]' have curved tops & bottoms and little something-or-others on their sides.  
 I'll try whatthefont again after I get a high-quality scan; right now it's just suggesting distressed fonts.  
—Joel

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414231912im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Just_in_Time_6690.png)
author: JCSalomon

comments.content: Looks like a Garamond to me?

Identifont suggested some Garamonds, but I didn't see the specific square bracket on them. Garamond 3 or American Garamond or something similar looks to be it.  
 Anybody know which version was in use on kerning-challenged typesetting machines _circa_ 1965?  
—Joel
